what: Clean up stale package lock files — clean_lock_files
title: Clean up stale package lock files — clean_lock_files
text: Removes stale lock directories can prevent package installation. Lock files created package installation automatically removed installation completes. installation interrupted (e.g., closing R crash), lock files may remain block future installations.

title: Clean up stale package lock files — clean_lock_files
code: clean_lock_files(package = "factoextraplus", lib = .libPaths()[1], ask = TRUE)

title: Clean up stale package lock files — clean_lock_files
text: package Character string specifying package lock remove. Default "factoextraplus". Use "" remove lock files. lib Library path check. Default first library .libPaths(). ask Logical. TRUE (default), asks confirmation removing.

title: Clean up stale package lock files — clean_lock_files
text: Invisibly returns TRUE files removed, FALSE otherwise.

title: Deprecated Functions — deprecated
text: Deprecated functions. removed future version. get_mfa_quanti_var(). Deprecated. Use get_mfa_var(res.mfa, "quanti.var") instead. get_mfa_quali_var().  Deprecated. Use get_mfa_var(res.mfa, "quali.var") instead. get_mfa_group(). Deprecated. Use get_mfa_var(res.mfa, "group") instead. fviz_mfa_ind_starplot(): Star graph individuals (draws partial points). Deprecated. Use fviz_mfa_ind(res.mfa, partial = "") instead. fviz_mfa_quanti_var(): Graph quantitative variables. Deprecated. Use fviz_mfa(X, "quanti.var") instead. fviz_mfa_quali_var(): Graph qualitative variables. Deprecated. Use fviz_mfa(X, "quali.var") instead. get_hmfa_quanti_var(). Deprecated. Use get_hmfa_var(res.hmfa, "quanti.var") instead. get_hmfa_quali_var().  Deprecated. Use get_hmfa_var(res.hmfa, "quali.var") instead. get_hmfa_group(). Deprecated. Use get_hmfa_var(res.hmfa, "group") instead. fviz_hmfa_ind_starplot(): Graph partial individuals. Deprecated. Use fviz_hmfa_ind(X, partial = "") instead. fviz_hmfa_quanti_var(): Graph quantitative variables. Deprecated. Use fviz_hmfa_var(X, "quanti.var") instead. fviz_hmfa_quali_var(): Graph qualitative variables. Deprecated. Use fviz_hmfa_var(X, "quali.var") instead. fviz_hmfa_group(): Graph groups representation. what: Enhanced Distance Matrix Computation and Visualization — dist
title: Enhanced Distance Matrix Computation and Visualization — dist
text: Clustering methods classify data samples groups similar   objects. process requires methods measuring distance   (dis)similarity observations. Read :   STHDA    website - clarifying distance measures.. get_dist():   Computes distance matrix rows data matrix. Compared   standard dist() function, supports   correlation-based distance measures including "pearson", "kendall"   "spearman" methods. fviz_dist(): Visualizes distance matrix

title: Enhanced Distance Matrix Computation and Visualization — dist
code: get_dist(x, method = "euclidean", stand = FALSE, ...)  fviz_dist(   dist.obj,   order = TRUE,   show_labels = TRUE,   lab_size = NULL,   gradient = list(low = "red", mid = "white", high = "blue") )

title: Enhanced Distance Matrix Computation and Visualization — dist
text: x numeric matrix data frame. method distance measure used. must one "euclidean", "maximum", "manhattan", "canberra", "binary", "minkowski", "pearson", "spearman" "kendall". stand logical value; default FALSE. TRUE, data standardized using function scale(). Measurements standardized variable (column), subtracting variable's mean value dividing variable's standard deviation. ... arguments passed function dist() using get_dist(). dist.obj object class "dist" generated function dist() get_dist(). order logical value. TRUE ordered dissimilarity image (ODI) shown. show_labels logical value. TRUE, labels displayed. lab_size size labels. gradient list containing three elements specifying colors low, mid high values ordered dissimilarity image. element "mid" can take value NULL.

title: Enhanced Distance Matrix Computation and Visualization — dist
text: get_dist(): returns object class "dist". fviz_dist(): returns ggplot2

title: Enhanced Distance Matrix Computation and Visualization — dist
text: Alboukadel Kassambara alboukadel.kassambara@gmail.com

title: Enhanced Distance Matrix Computation and Visualization — dist
code: data(USArrests) res.dist <- get_dist(USArrests, stand = TRUE, method = "pearson")  fviz_dist(res.dist,     gradient = list(low = "#00AFBB", mid = "white", high = "#FC4E07"))

what: Visual enhancement of clustering analysis — eclust
title: Visual enhancement of clustering analysis — eclust
text: Provides solution enhancing workflow clustering   analyses ggplot2-based elegant data visualization. Read :  Visual enhancement clustering analysis.

title: Visual enhancement of clustering analysis — eclust
code: eclust(   x,   FUNcluster = c("kmeans", "pam", "clara", "fanny", "hclust", "agnes", "diana"),   k = NULL,   k.max = 10,   stand = FALSE,   graph = TRUE,   hc_metric = "euclidean",   hc_method = "ward.D2",   gap_maxSE = list(method = "firstSEmax", SE.factor = 1),   nboot = 100,   verbose = interactive(),   seed = 123,   ... )

title: Visual enhancement of clustering analysis — eclust
text: x numeric vector, data matrix data frame FUNcluster clustering function including "kmeans", "pam", "clara", "fanny", "hclust", "agnes" "diana". Abbreviation allowed. k number clusters generated. NULL, gap statistic used estimate appropriate number clusters. case kmeans, k can either number clusters, set initial (distinct) cluster centers. k.max maximum number clusters consider, must least two. stand logical value; default FALSE. TRUE, data standardized using function scale(). Measurements standardized variable (column), subtracting variable's mean value dividing variable's standard deviation. graph logical value. TRUE, cluster plot displayed. hc_metric character string specifying metric used calculating dissimilarities observations. Allowed values accepted function dist() [including "euclidean", "manhattan", "maximum", "canberra", "binary", "minkowski"] correlation based distance measures ["pearson", "spearman" "kendall"]. Used FUNcluster hierarchical clustering function one "hclust", "agnes" "diana". hc_method agglomeration method used (?hclust): "ward.D", "ward.D2", "single", "complete", "average", ... gap_maxSE list containing parameters (method SE.factor) determining location maximum gap statistic (Read documentation ?cluster::maxSE). nboot integer, number Monte Carlo ("bootstrap") samples. Used determining number clusters using gap statistic. verbose logical value. TRUE, result progress printed. seed integer used seeding random number generator. ... arguments passed FUNcluster.

title: Visual enhancement of clustering analysis — eclust
text: Returns object class "eclust" containing result   standard function used (e.g., kmeans, pam, hclust, agnes, diana, etc.). includes also: cluster: cluster assignement   observations cutting tree nbclust: number clusters silinfo: silhouette information observations, including   $widths (silhouette width values observation), $clus.avg.widths   (average silhouette width cluster) $avg.width (average width   clusters) size: size clusters data: matrix   containing original standardized data (stand = TRUE)   "eclust" class method fviz_silhouette(), fviz_dend(),   fviz_cluster().

title: Visual enhancement of clustering analysis — eclust
text: Alboukadel Kassambara alboukadel.kassambara@gmail.com

what: Extract and visualize the eigenvalues/variances of dimensions — eigenvalue
title: Extract and visualize the eigenvalues/variances of dimensions — eigenvalue
text: Eigenvalues correspond amount variation explained  principal component (PC).  get_eig(): Extract eigenvalues/variances  principal dimensions fviz_eig(): Plot eigenvalues/variances  number dimensions get_eigenvalue(): alias  get_eig() fviz_screeplot(): alias fviz_eig() functions support results Principal Component Analysis (PCA),  Correspondence Analysis (CA), Multiple Correspondence Analysis (MCA), Factor Analysis Mixed Data (FAMD),  Multiple Factor Analysis (MFA) Hierarchical Multiple Factor Analysis  (HMFA) functions.

title: Extract and visualize the eigenvalues/variances of dimensions — eigenvalue
code: get_eig(X)  get_eigenvalue(X)  fviz_eig(   X,   choice = c("variance", "eigenvalue"),   geom = c("bar", "line"),   barfill = "steelblue",   barcolor = "steelblue",   linecolor = "black",   ncp = 10,   addlabels = FALSE,   hjust = 0,   main = NULL,   xlab = NULL,   ylab = NULL,   ggtheme = theme_minimal(),   parallel = FALSE,   parallel.color = "red",   parallel.lty = "dashed",   parallel.iter = 100,   ... )  fviz_screeplot(...)

title: Extract and visualize the eigenvalues/variances of dimensions — eigenvalue
text: X object class PCA, CA, MCA, FAMD, MFA HMFA [FactoMineR]; prcomp princomp [stats]; dudi, pca, coa acm [ade4]; ca mjca [ca package]. choice text specifying data plotted. Allowed values "variance" "eigenvalue". geom text specifying geometry used graph. Allowed values "bar" barplot, "line" lineplot c("bar", "line") use types. barfill fill color bar plot. barcolor outline color bar plot. linecolor color line plot (geom contains "line"). ncp numeric value specifying number dimensions shown. addlabels logical value. TRUE, labels added top bars points showing information retained dimension. hjust horizontal adjustment labels. main, xlab, ylab plot main axis titles. ggtheme function, ggplot2 theme name. Default value theme_pubr(). Allowed values include ggplot2 official themes: theme_gray(), theme_bw(), theme_minimal(), theme_classic(), theme_void(), .... parallel logical value. TRUE, adds parallel analysis threshold line (Horn's method) help determine number components retain. Components eigenvalues line considered significant. works choice = "eigenvalue" X prcomp princomp object. Default FALSE. parallel.color color parallel analysis threshold line. Default "red". parallel.lty line type parallel analysis line. Default "dashed". parallel.iter number iterations parallel analysis simulation. Default 100. ... optional arguments passed function ggpar.

title: Extract and visualize the eigenvalues/variances of dimensions — eigenvalue
text: get_eig() (get_eigenvalue()): returns data.frame  containing 3 columns: eigenvalues, percentage variance   cumulative percentage variance retained dimension. fviz_eig() (fviz_screeplot()): returns ggplot2

title: Extract and visualize the eigenvalues/variances of dimensions — eigenvalue
text: Alboukadel Kassambara alboukadel.kassambara@gmail.com

title: Extract and visualize the eigenvalues/variances of dimensions — eigenvalue
code: # Principal Component Analysis # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++ data(iris) res.pca <- prcomp(iris[, -5],  scale = TRUE)  # Extract eigenvalues/variances get_eig(res.pca) #>       eigenvalue variance.percent cumulative.variance.percent #> Dim.1 2.91849782       72.9624454                    72.96245 #> Dim.2 0.91403047       22.8507618                    95.81321 #> Dim.3 0.14675688        3.6689219                    99.48213 #> Dim.4 0.02071484        0.5178709                   100.00000  # Default plot fviz_eig(res.pca, addlabels = TRUE, ylim = c(0, 85))     # Scree plot - Eigenvalues fviz_eig(res.pca, choice = "eigenvalue", addlabels=TRUE)   # Use only bar  or line plot: geom = "bar" or geom = "line" fviz_eig(res.pca, geom="line")   # Parallel analysis (Horn's method) to determine number of components # Components with eigenvalues above the red line are significant fviz_eig(res.pca, choice = "eigenvalue", parallel = TRUE,          addlabels = TRUE, parallel.color = "red")   if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{          # Correspondence Analysis # +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ library(FactoMineR) data(housetasks) res.ca <- CA(housetasks, graph = FALSE) get_eig(res.ca) fviz_eig(res.ca, linecolor = "#FC4E07",    barcolor = "#00AFBB", barfill = "#00AFBB")  # Multiple Correspondence Analysis # +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ library(FactoMineR) data(poison) res.mca <- MCA(poison, quanti.sup = 1:2,                quali.sup = 3:4, graph=FALSE) get_eig(res.mca) fviz_eig(res.mca, linecolor = "#FC4E07",    barcolor = "#2E9FDF", barfill = "#2E9FDF") } # }

what: factoextraplus: Extract and Visualize the Results of Multivariate Data Analyses (Extended) — factoextraplus-package
title: factoextraplus: Extract and Visualize the Results of Multivariate Data Analyses (Extended) — factoextraplus-package
text: Supplementary compatibility updates factoextra (Kassambara & Mundt, 2020). Modern R ecosystem support (ggplot2 >= 4.0.0, R >= 4.1.0) - cited original package. Provides easy--use functions extract visualize output multivariate data analyses, including 'PCA' (Principal Component Analysis), 'CA' (Correspondence Analysis), 'MCA' (Multiple Correspondence Analysis), 'FAMD' (Factor Analysis Mixed Data), 'MFA' (Multiple Factor Analysis) 'HMFA' (Hierarchical Multiple Factor Analysis) functions different R packages. contains also functions simplifying clustering analysis steps provides 'ggplot2'-based elegant data visualization.

Allowed values "none" combination c("ind", "ind.sup", "quali", "var", "quanti.sup", "group.sup"). "ind" can used label active individuals. "ind.sup" supplementary individuals. "quali" supplementary qualitative variables. "var" active variables. "quanti.sup" quantitative supplementary variables. invisible text specifying elements hidden plot. Default value "none". Allowed values combination c("ind", "ind.sup", "quali", "var", "quanti.sup", "group.sup"). labelsize font size labels pointsize size points pointshape shape points arrowsize size arrows. Controls thickness arrows. habillage optional factor variable coloring observations groups. Default value "none". X PCA object FactoMineR package, habillage can also specify supplementary qualitative variable (index name) used coloring individuals groups (see ?PCA FactoMineR). addEllipses logical value. TRUE, draws ellipses around individuals habillage != "none". ellipse.level size concentration ellipse normal probability. ellipse.type Character specifying frame type. Possible values "convex", "confidence" types supported stat_ellipse() including one c("t", "norm", "euclid") plotting concentration ellipses. "convex": plot convex hull set points. "confidence": plot confidence ellipses around group mean points coord.ellipse()[FactoMineR]. "t": assumes multivariate t-distribution. "norm": assumes multivariate normal distribution. "euclid": draws circle radius equal level, representing euclidean distance center. ellipse probably appear circular unless coord_fixed() applied. ellipse.alpha Alpha ellipse specifying transparency level fill color. Use alpha = 0 fill color. mean.point logical value. TRUE (default), group mean points added plot. color color used specified geometries (point, text). Can continuous variable factor variable. Possible values include also : "cos2", "contrib", "coord", "x" "y". case, colors individuals/variables automatically controlled qualities representation ("cos2"), contributions ("contrib"), coordinates (x^2+y^2, "coord"), x values ("x") y values ("y"). use automatic coloring (cos2, contrib, ....), make sure habillage ="none". fill argument color, point fill color. Useful pointshape = 21, example. alpha controls transparency individual variable colors, respectively. value can variate 0 (total transparency) 1 (transparency). Default value 1. Possible values include also : "cos2", "contrib", "coord", "x" "y". case, transparency individual/variable colors automatically controlled qualities ("cos2"), contributions ("contrib"), coordinates (x^2+y^2, "coord"), x values("x") y values("y"). use , make sure habillage ="none". gradient.cols vector colors use n-colour gradient. Allowed values include brewer ggsci color palettes. col.col.sup, col.row.sup colors supplementary column row points, respectively. select selection individuals/variables drawn. Allowed values NULL list containing arguments name, cos2 contrib: name: character vector containing individuals/variables drawn cos2: cos2 [0, 1], ex: 0.6, individuals/variables cos2 > 0.6 drawn. cos2 > 1, ex: 5, top 5 individuals/variables highest cos2 drawn. contrib: contrib > 1, ex: 5,  top 5 individuals/variables highest contrib drawn title title graph axes.linetype linetype x y axes. repel boolean, whether use ggrepel avoid overplotting text labels . old jitter argument kept backward compatibility silently converted repel = TRUE. col.circle color correlation circle. Used X PCA output. circlesize size variable correlation circle. ggtheme function, ggplot2 theme name. Default value theme_pubr(). Allowed values include ggplot2 official themes: theme_gray(), theme_bw(), theme_minimal(), theme_classic(), theme_void(), .... ggp ggplot. NULL, points added existing plot. font.family character vector specifying font family. ... Arguments passed functions ggpubrplus::ggscatter() & ggpubrplus::ggpar().

title: Visualize Correspondence Analysis — fviz_ca
text: default plot (M)CA "symmetric" plot rows  columns principal coordinates. situation,  possible interpret distance row points column points.  overcome problem, simplest way make asymmetric plot.  means , column profiles must presented row space  vice-versa. allowed options argument map : "rowprincipal" "colprincipal": asymmetric plots either rows  principal coordinates columns standard coordinates, vice versa.  plots preserve row metric column metric respectively. "symbiplot": rows columns scaled variances equal  singular values (square roots eigenvalues), gives symmetric  biplot preserve row column metrics. "rowgab"  "colgab": Asymmetric maps, proposed Gabriel & Odoroff (1990), rows  (respectively, columns) principal coordinates columns (respectively,  rows) standard coordinates multiplied mass corresponding  point. "rowgreen" "colgreen": -called contribution biplots  showing visually contributing points (Greenacre 2006b).  similar "rowgab" "colgab" except points standard  coordinates multiplied square root corresponding masses,  giving reconstructions standardized residuals.

title: Visualize Correspondence Analysis — fviz_ca
text: Alboukadel Kassambara alboukadel.kassambara@gmail.com

title: Visualize Correspondence Analysis — fviz_ca
code: # Correspondence Analysis # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ # Install and load FactoMineR to compute CA # install.packages("FactoMineR")  library("FactoMineR") data(housetasks) head(housetasks) #>            Wife Alternating Husband Jointly #> Laundry     156          14       2       4 #> Main_meal   124          20       5       4 #> Dinner       77          11       7      13 #> Breakfeast   82          36      15       7 #> Tidying      53          11       1      57 #> Dishes       32          24       4      53 res.ca <- CA(housetasks, graph=FALSE)  # Biplot of rows and columns # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++ # Symetric Biplot of rows and columns fviz_ca_biplot(res.ca)   # Asymetric biplot, use arrows for columns fviz_ca_biplot(res.ca, map ="rowprincipal",  arrow = c(FALSE, TRUE))    # Keep only the labels for row points fviz_ca_biplot(res.ca, label ="row")   # Keep only labels for column points fviz_ca_biplot(res.ca, label ="col")           # Select the top 7 contributing rows # And the top 3 columns fviz_ca_biplot(res.ca,                  select.row = list(contrib = 7),                select.col = list(contrib = 3))   # Graph of row variables # +++++++++++++++++++++     # Control automatically the color of row points    # using the "cos2" or the contributions "contrib"    # cos2 = the quality of the rows on the factor map    # Change gradient color    # Use repel = TRUE to avoid overplotting (slow if many points) fviz_ca_row(res.ca, col.row = "cos2",    gradient.cols = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800", "#FC4E07"),    repel = TRUE)   # You can also control the transparency  # of the color by the "cos2" or "contrib" fviz_ca_row(res.ca, alpha.row="contrib")          # Select and visualize some rows with select.row argument.  # - Rows with cos2 >= 0.5: select.row = list(cos2 = 0.5)  # - Top 7 rows according to the cos2: select.row = list(cos2 = 7)  # - Top 7 contributing rows: select.row = list(contrib = 7)  # - Select rows by names: select.row = list(name = c("Breakfeast", "Repairs", "Holidays"))    # Example: Select the top 7 contributing rows fviz_ca_row(res.ca, select.row = list(contrib = 7))     # Graph of column points # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++    # Control colors using their contributions fviz_ca_col(res.ca, col.col = "contrib",    gradient.cols = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800", "#FC4E07"))          # Select columns with select.col argument    # You can select by contrib, cos2 and name     # as previously described for ind # Select the top 3 contributing columns fviz_ca_col(res.ca, select.col = list(contrib = 3))

title: Visualize Clustering Results — fviz_cluster
text: Alboukadel Kassambara alboukadel.kassambara@gmail.com

title: Visualize Clustering Results — fviz_cluster
code: set.seed(123)  # Data preparation # +++++++++++++++ data("iris") head(iris) #>   Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species #> 1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 2          4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa #> 4          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa #> 5          5.0         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa # Remove species column (5) and scale the data iris.scaled <- scale(iris[, -5])  # K-means clustering # +++++++++++++++++++++ km.res <- kmeans(iris.scaled, 3, nstart = 10)  # Visualize kmeans clustering # use repel = TRUE to avoid overplotting fviz_cluster(km.res, iris[, -5], ellipse.type = "norm")    # Change the color palette and theme fviz_cluster(km.res, iris[, -5],    palette = "Set2", ggtheme = theme_minimal())    if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Show points only fviz_cluster(km.res, iris[, -5], geom = "point") # Show text only fviz_cluster(km.res, iris[, -5], geom = "text")  # PAM clustering # ++++++++++++++++++++ require(cluster) pam.res <- pam(iris.scaled, 3)  # Visualize pam clustering fviz_cluster(pam.res, geom = "point", ellipse.type = "norm")  # Hierarchical clustering # ++++++++++++++++++++++++ # Use hcut() which compute hclust and cut the tree hc.cut <- hcut(iris.scaled, k = 3, hc_method = "complete") # Visualize dendrogram fviz_dend(hc.cut, show_labels = FALSE, rect = TRUE) # Visualize cluster fviz_cluster(hc.cut, ellipse.type = "convex")  } # }

Visualize individual contributions on axes 1 fviz_contrib(res.mfa, choice ="ind", axes = 1, top = 20) # Visualize catecorical variable categorie contributions on axes 1 fviz_contrib(res.mfa, choice ="quali.var", axes = 1) } # code: # \donttest{ # Principal component analysis # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++ data(decathlon2) decathlon2.active <- decathlon2[1:23, 1:10] res.pca <- prcomp(decathlon2.active,  scale = TRUE)  # variable cos2 on axis 1 fviz_cos2(res.pca, choice="var", axes = 1, top = 10 )   # Change color fviz_cos2(res.pca, choice="var", axes = 1,          fill = "lightgray", color = "black")             # Variable cos2 on axes 1 + 2 fviz_cos2(res.pca, choice="var", axes = 1:2)   # cos2 of individuals on axis 1 fviz_cos2(res.pca, choice="ind", axes = 1)   if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Correspondence Analysis # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++ library("FactoMineR") data("housetasks") res.ca <- CA(housetasks, graph = FALSE)  # Visualize row cos2 on axes 1 fviz_cos2(res.ca, choice ="row", axes = 1) # Visualize column cos2 on axes 1 fviz_cos2(res.ca, choice ="col", axes = 1)  # Multiple Correspondence Analysis # +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ library(FactoMineR) data(poison) res.mca <- MCA(poison, quanti.sup = 1:2,                quali.sup = 3:4, graph=FALSE)                # Visualize individual cos2 on axes 1 fviz_cos2(res.mca, choice ="ind", axes = 1, top = 20) # Visualize variable categorie cos2 on axes 1 fviz_cos2(res.mca, choice ="var", axes = 1)  # Multiple Factor Analysis # ++++++++++++++++++++++++ library(FactoMineR) data(poison) res.mfa <- MFA(poison, group=c(2,2,5,6), type=c("s","n","n","n"),                name.group=c("desc","desc2","symptom","eat"),                num.group.sup=1:2, graph=FALSE) # Visualize individual cos2 on axes 1 # Select the top 20 fviz_cos2(res.mfa, choice ="ind", axes = 1, top = 20) # Visualize catecorical variable categorie cos2 on axes 1 fviz_cos2(res.mfa, choice ="quali.var", axes = 1) } # }                  # }

title: Enhanced Visualization of Dendrogram — fviz_dend
text: Draws easily beautiful dendrograms using either R base plot   ggplot2. Provides also option drawing circular dendrogram   phylogenic trees.

title: Enhanced Visualization of Dendrogram — fviz_dend
code: fviz_dend(   x,   k = NULL,   h = NULL,   k_colors = NULL,   palette = NULL,   show_labels = TRUE,   color_labels_by_k = TRUE,   label_cols = NULL,   labels_track_height = NULL,   repel = FALSE,   lwd = 0.7,   type = c("rectangle", "circular", "phylogenic"),   phylo_layout = "layout.auto",   rect = FALSE,   rect_border = "gray",   rect_lty = 2,   rect_fill = FALSE,   lower_rect,   horiz = FALSE,   cex = 0.8,   main = "Cluster Dendrogram",   xlab = "",   ylab = "Height",   sub = NULL,   ggtheme = theme_classic(),   ... )

title: Enhanced Visualization of Dendrogram — fviz_dend
text: x object class dendrogram, hclust, agnes, diana, hcut, hkmeans HCPC (FactoMineR). k number groups cutting tree. h numeric value. Cut dendrogram cutting height h. (k overrides h) k_colors, palette vector containing colors used groups. contains k number colors. Allowed values include also "grey" grey color palettes; brewer palettes e.g. "RdBu", "Blues", ...;  scientific journal palettes ggsci R package, e.g.: "npg", "aaas", "lancet", "jco", "ucscgb", "uchicago", "simpsons" "rickandmorty". show_labels logical value. TRUE, leaf labels shown. Default value TRUE. color_labels_by_k logical value. TRUE, labels colored automatically group k != NULL. label_cols vector containing colors labels. labels_track_height positive numeric value adjusting room labels. Used type = "rectangle". repel logical value. Use repel = TRUE avoid label overplotting type = "phylogenic". lwd numeric value specifying branches rectangle line width. type type plot. Allowed values one "rectangle", "triangle", "circular", "phylogenic". phylo_layout layout used phylogenic trees. Default value "layout.auto". Allowed values include: layout.auto, layout_with_drl, layout_as_tree, layout.gem, layout.mds layout_with_lgl. rect logical value specifying whether add rectangle around groups. Used k != NULL. rect_border, rect_lty border color line type rectangles. rect_fill logical value. TRUE, fill rectangle. lower_rect value low lower part rectangle around clusters. Ignored rect = FALSE. horiz logical value. TRUE, horizontal dendrogram drawn. cex size labels main, xlab, ylab main axis titles sub Plot subtitle. NULL, method used hierarchical clustering shown. remove subtitle use sub = "". ggtheme function, ggplot2 theme name. Default value theme_classic(). Allowed values include ggplot2 official themes: theme_gray(), theme_bw(), theme_minimal(), theme_classic(), theme_void(), .... ... arguments passed function plot.dendrogram()

title: Enhanced Visualization of Dendrogram — fviz_dend
text: object class fviz_dend ggplot attributes   "dendrogram" accessible using attr(x, "dendrogram"), x result   fviz_dend().

title: Enhanced Visualization of Dendrogram — fviz_dend
code: # \donttest{ # Load and scale the data data(USArrests) df <- scale(USArrests)  # Hierarchical clustering res.hc <- hclust(dist(df))  # Default plot fviz_dend(res.hc)   # Cut the tree fviz_dend(res.hc, cex = 0.5, k = 4, color_labels_by_k = TRUE)   # Don't color labels, add rectangles fviz_dend(res.hc, cex = 0.5, k = 4,   color_labels_by_k = FALSE, rect = TRUE)    # Change the color of tree using black color for all groups # Change rectangle border colors fviz_dend(res.hc, rect = TRUE, k_colors ="black", rect_border = 2:5, rect_lty = 1)   # Customized color for groups fviz_dend(res.hc, k = 4,   k_colors = c("#1B9E77", "#D95F02", "#7570B3", "#E7298A"))       # Color labels using k-means clusters  km.clust <- kmeans(df, 4)$cluster  fviz_dend(res.hc, k = 4,     k_colors = c("blue", "green3", "red", "black"),    label_cols =  km.clust[res.hc$order], cex = 0.6)   # }

title: Draw confidence ellipses around the categories — fviz_ellipses
code: fviz_ellipses(   X,   habillage,   axes = c(1, 2),   addEllipses = TRUE,   ellipse.type = "confidence",   palette = NULL,   pointsize = 1,   geom = c("point", "text"),   ggtheme = theme_bw(),   ... )

title: Draw confidence ellipses around the categories — fviz_ellipses
text: X object class MCA, PCA MFA. habillage numeric vector indexes variables character vector names variables. Can also data frame containing grouping variables. axes numeric vector specifying axes interest. Default values 1:2 axes 1 2. addEllipses logical value. TRUE, draws ellipses around individuals habillage != "none". ellipse.type Character specifying frame type. Possible values "convex", "confidence" types supported stat_ellipse() including one c("t", "norm", "euclid") plotting concentration ellipses. "convex": plot convex hull set points. "confidence": plot confidence ellipses around group mean points coord.ellipse()[FactoMineR]. "t": assumes multivariate t-distribution. "norm": assumes multivariate normal distribution. "euclid": draws circle radius equal level, representing euclidean distance center. ellipse probably appear circular unless coord_fixed() applied. palette color palette used coloring filling groups. Allowed values include "grey" grey color palettes; brewer palettes e.g. "RdBu", "Blues", ...; custom color palette e.g. c("blue", "red"); scientific journal palettes ggsci R package, e.g.: "npg", "aaas", "lancet", "jco", "ucscgb", "uchicago", "simpsons" "rickandmorty". Can also numeric vector length(groups); case basic color palette created using function palette. pointsize size points geom text specifying geometry used graph.  Allowed values combination c("point", "text"). Use "point" (show points); "text" show labels; c("point", "text") show types. ggtheme function, ggplot2 theme name. Default value theme_pubr(). Allowed values include ggplot2 official themes: theme_gray(), theme_bw(), theme_minimal(), theme_classic(), theme_void(), .... ... Arguments passed functions ggpubrplus::ggscatter()  & ggpubrplus::ggpar().

title: Visualize Factor Analysis of Mixed Data — fviz_famd
text: X object class FAMD [FactoMineR]. axes numeric vector length 2 specifying dimensions plotted. geom text specifying geometry used graph. Allowed values combination c("point", "arrow", "text"). Use "point" (show points); "text" show labels; c("point", "text") c("arrow", "text") show arrows texts. Using c("arrow", "text") sensible graph variables. repel boolean, whether use ggrepel avoid overplotting text labels . old jitter argument kept backward compatibility silently converted repel = TRUE. habillage optional factor variable coloring observations groups. Default value "none". X MFA object FactoMineR package, habillage can also specify index factor variable data. palette color palette used coloring filling groups. Allowed values include "grey" grey color palettes; brewer palettes e.g. "RdBu", "Blues", ...; custom color palette e.g. c("blue", "red"); scientific journal palettes ggsci R package, e.g.: "npg", "aaas", "lancet", "jco", "ucscgb", "uchicago", "simpsons" "rickandmorty". Can also numeric vector length(groups); case basic color palette created using function palette. addEllipses logical value. TRUE, draws ellipses around individuals habillage != "none". col.ind, col.var color individuals variables, respectively. Can continuous variable factor variable. Possible values include also : "cos2", "contrib", "coord", "x" "y". case, colors individuals/variables automatically controlled qualities ("cos2"), contributions ("contrib"), coordinates (x^2 + y^2 , "coord"), x values("x") y values("y"). use automatic coloring (cos2, contrib, ....), make sure habillage ="none". col.ind.sup color supplementary individuals alpha.ind, alpha.var controls transparency individuals variables, respectively. value can variate 0 (total transparency) 1 (transparency). Default value 1. Possible values include also : "cos2", "contrib", "coord", "x" "y". case, transparency individual/variable colors automatically controlled qualities ("cos2"), contributions ("contrib"), coordinates (x^2 + y^2 , "coord"), x values("x") y values("y"). use , make sure habillage ="none". shape.ind, shape.var point shapes individuals, variables, groups axes col.quali.var color qualitative variables fviz_mfa_ind(). Default "black". select.ind, select.var selection individuals variables drawn. Allowed values NULL list containing arguments name, cos2 contrib: name character vector containing individuals/variables drawn cos2 cos2 [0, 1], ex: 0.6, individuals/variables cos2 > 0.6 drawn. cos2 > 1, ex: 5, top 5 individuals/variables highest cos2 drawn. contrib contrib > 1, ex: 5,  top 5 individuals/variables highest cos2 drawn gradient.cols vector colors use n-colour gradient. Allowed values include brewer ggsci color palettes. ... Arguments passed function fviz() choice graph plot inf fviz_mfa_var(). Allowed values include one c("var", quanti.var",  "quali.var"). col.var.sup color supplementary variables.

title: Visualize Hierarchical Multiple Factor Analysis — fviz_hmfa
text: Fabian Mundt f.mundt@inventionate.de Alboukadel Kassambara alboukadel.kassambara@gmail.com

title: Visualize Hierarchical Multiple Factor Analysis — fviz_hmfa
code: # Hierarchical Multiple Factor Analysis # ++++++++++++++++++++++++ # Install and load FactoMineR to compute MFA # install.packages("FactoMineR") library("FactoMineR") data(wine) hierar <- list(c(2,5,3,10,9,2), c(4,2)) res.hmfa <- HMFA(wine, H = hierar, type=c("n",rep("s",5)), graph = FALSE)  # Graph of individuals # ++++++++++++++++++++ # Color of individuals: col.ind = "#2E9FDF" # Use repel = TRUE to avoid overplotting (slow if many points) fviz_hmfa_ind(res.hmfa, repel = TRUE, col.ind = "#2E9FDF")   # Color individuals by groups, add concentration ellipses # Remove labels: label = "none". # Change color palette to "jco". See ?ggpubrplus::ggpar grp <- as.factor(wine[,1]) p <- fviz_hmfa_ind(res.hmfa, label="none", habillage=grp,        addEllipses=TRUE, palette = "jco") print(p)     # Graph of variables # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ # Quantitative variables fviz_hmfa_var(res.hmfa, "quanti.var")  # Graph of categorical variable categories fviz_hmfa_var(res.hmfa, "quali.var")  # Groups of variables (correlation square) fviz_hmfa_var(res.hmfa, "group")    # Biplot of categorical variable categories and individuals # +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ fviz_hmfa_quali_biplot(res.hmfa)       # Graph of partial individuals (starplot) # +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ fviz_hmfa_ind(res.hmfa, partial = "all", palette = "Dark2")

code: # Multiple Correspondence Analysis # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ # Install and load FactoMineR to compute MCA # install.packages("FactoMineR") library("FactoMineR") data(poison) poison.active <- poison[1:55, 5:15] head(poison.active) #>     Nausea Vomiting Abdominals   Fever   Diarrhae   Potato   Fish   Mayo #> 1 Nausea_y  Vomit_n     Abdo_y Fever_y Diarrhea_y Potato_y Fish_y Mayo_y #> 2 Nausea_n  Vomit_n     Abdo_n Fever_n Diarrhea_n Potato_y Fish_y Mayo_y #> 3 Nausea_n  Vomit_y     Abdo_y Fever_y Diarrhea_y Potato_y Fish_y Mayo_y #> 4 Nausea_n  Vomit_n     Abdo_n Fever_n Diarrhea_n Potato_y Fish_y Mayo_n #> 5 Nausea_n  Vomit_y     Abdo_y Fever_y Diarrhea_y Potato_y Fish_y Mayo_y #> 6 Nausea_n  Vomit_n     Abdo_y Fever_y Diarrhea_y Potato_y Fish_n Mayo_y #>   Courgette   Cheese   Icecream #> 1   Courg_y Cheese_y Icecream_y #> 2   Courg_y Cheese_n Icecream_y #> 3   Courg_y Cheese_y Icecream_y #> 4   Courg_y Cheese_y Icecream_y #> 5   Courg_y Cheese_y Icecream_y #> 6   Courg_y Cheese_y Icecream_y res.mca <- MCA(poison.active, graph=FALSE)  # Graph of individuals # +++++++++++++++++++++  # Default Plot # Color of individuals: col.ind = "steelblue" fviz_mca_ind(res.mca, col.ind = "steelblue")   # 1. Control automatically the color of individuals     # using the "cos2" or the contributions "contrib"    # cos2 = the quality of the individuals on the factor map # 2. To keep only point or text use geom = "point" or geom = "text". # 3. Change themes: http://www.sthda.com/english/wiki/ggplot2-themes  fviz_mca_ind(res.mca, col.ind = "cos2", repel = TRUE)   if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{      # You can also control the transparency  # of the color by the cos2 fviz_mca_ind(res.mca, alpha.ind="cos2")  } # }       # Color individuals by groups, add concentration ellipses # Remove labels: label = "none". grp <- as.factor(poison.active[, "Vomiting"]) p <- fviz_mca_ind(res.mca, label="none", habillage=grp,        addEllipses=TRUE, ellipse.level=0.95) print(p)              # Change group colors using RColorBrewer color palettes # Read more: http://www.sthda.com/english/wiki/ggplot2-colors p + scale_color_brewer(palette="Dark2") +     scale_fill_brewer(palette="Dark2")         # Change group colors manually # Read more: http://www.sthda.com/english/wiki/ggplot2-colors p + scale_color_manual(values=c("#999999", "#E69F00"))+  scale_fill_manual(values=c("#999999", "#E69F00"))                              # Select and visualize some individuals (ind) with select.ind argument.  # - ind with cos2 >= 0.4: select.ind = list(cos2 = 0.4)  # - Top 20 ind according to the cos2: select.ind = list(cos2 = 20)  # - Top 20 contributing individuals: select.ind = list(contrib = 20)  # - Select ind by names: select.ind = list(name = c("44", "38", "53",  "39") )   # Example: Select the top 40 according to the cos2 fviz_mca_ind(res.mca, select.ind = list(cos2 = 20))     # Graph of variable categories # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ # Default plot: use repel = TRUE to avoid overplotting fviz_mca_var(res.mca, col.var = "#FC4E07")   # Control variable colors using their contributions # use repel = TRUE to avoid overplotting fviz_mca_var(res.mca, col.var = "contrib",   gradient.cols = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800", "#FC4E07"))                # Biplot # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++ grp <- as.factor(poison.active[, "Vomiting"]) fviz_mca_biplot(res.mca, repel = TRUE, col.var = "#E7B800",  habillage = grp, addEllipses = TRUE, ellipse.level = 0.95)     if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Keep only the labels for variable categories:  fviz_mca_biplot(res.mca, label ="var")  # Keep only labels for individuals fviz_mca_biplot(res.mca, label ="ind")  # Hide variable categories fviz_mca_biplot(res.mca, invisible ="var")  # Hide individuals fviz_mca_biplot(res.mca, invisible ="ind")  # Control automatically the color of individuals using the cos2 fviz_mca_biplot(res.mca, label ="var", col.ind="cos2")         # Change the color by groups, add ellipses fviz_mca_biplot(res.mca, label="var", col.var ="blue",    habillage=grp, addEllipses=TRUE, ellipse.level=0.95)                 # Select the top 30 contributing individuals # And the top 10 variables fviz_mca_biplot(res.mca,                  select.ind = list(contrib = 30),                select.var = list(contrib = 10))  } # }

title: Plot Model-Based Clustering Results using ggplot2 — fviz_mclust

title: Plot Model-Based Clustering Results using ggplot2 — fviz_mclust
code: fviz_mclust(   object,   what = c("classification", "uncertainty", "BIC"),   ellipse.type = "norm",   ellipse.level = 0.4,   ggtheme = theme_classic(),   ... )  fviz_mclust_bic(   object,   model.names = NULL,   shape = 19,   color = "model",   palette = NULL,   legend = NULL,   main = "Model selection",   xlab = "Number of components",   ylab = "BIC",   ... )

title: Plot Model-Based Clustering Results using ggplot2 — fviz_mclust
text: object object class Mclust choose one following three options: "classification" (default), "uncertainty" "BIC". ellipse.type Character specifying frame type. Possible values 'convex', 'confidence' types supported stat_ellipse including one c("t", "norm", "euclid"). ellipse.level size concentration ellipse normal probability. Passed ggplot2::stat_ellipse 's level. Ignored 'convex'. Default value 0.95. ggtheme function, ggplot2 theme name. Default value theme_pubr(). Allowed values include ggplot2 official themes: theme_gray(), theme_bw(), theme_minimal(), theme_classic(), theme_void(), .... ... arguments passed functions fviz_cluster ggpar. model.names one model names corresponding models fit object. default plot BIC models fit. shape point shape. change point shape model names use shape = "model". color point line color. palette color palette used coloring filling groups. Allowed values include "grey" grey color palettes; brewer palettes e.g. "RdBu", "Blues", ...; custom color palette e.g. c("blue", "red"); scientific journal palettes ggsci R package, e.g.: "npg", "aaas", "lancet", "jco", "ucscgb", "uchicago", "simpsons" "rickandmorty". Can also numeric vector length(groups); case basic color palette created using function palette. legend character specifying legend position. Allowed values one c("top", "bottom", "left", "right", "none"). remove legend use legend = "none". Legend position can also specified using numeric vector c(x, y); see details section. main plot main title. xlab character vector specifying x axis labels. Use xlab = FALSE hide xlab. ylab character vector specifying y axis labels. Use ylab = FALSE hide ylab.

title: Plot Model-Based Clustering Results using ggplot2 — fviz_mclust
text: fviz_mclust(): Plots classification uncertainty. fviz_mclust_bic(): Plots BIC values.

code: fviz_mfa_ind(   X,   axes = c(1, 2),   geom = c("point", "text"),   repel = FALSE,   habillage = "none",   palette = NULL,   addEllipses = FALSE,   col.ind = "blue",   col.ind.sup = "darkblue",   alpha.ind = 1,   shape.ind = 19,   col.quali.var.sup = "black",   select.ind = list(name = NULL, cos2 = NULL, contrib = NULL),   partial = NULL,   col.partial = "group",   ... )  fviz_mfa_quali_biplot(   X,   axes = c(1, 2),   geom = c("point", "text"),   repel = repel,   title = "Biplot of individuals and qualitative variables - MFA",   ... )  fviz_mfa_var(   X,   choice = c("quanti.var", "group", "quali.var"),   axes = c(1, 2),   geom = c("point", "text"),   repel = FALSE,   habillage = "none",   col.var = "red",   alpha.var = 1,   shape.var = 17,   col.var.sup = "darkgreen",   palette = NULL,   select.var = list(name = NULL, cos2 = NULL, contrib = NULL),   ... )  fviz_mfa_axes(   X,   axes = c(1, 2),   geom = c("arrow", "text"),   col.axes = NULL,   alpha.axes = 1,   col.circle = "grey70",   select.axes = list(name = NULL, contrib = NULL),   repel = FALSE,   ... )  fviz_mfa(X, partial = "all", ...)

Can also numeric vector length(groups); case basic color palette created using function palette. addEllipses logical value. TRUE, draws ellipses around individuals habillage != "none". col.ind, col.var, col.axes color individuals, variables col.axes respectively. Can continuous variable factor variable. Possible values include also : "cos2", "contrib", "coord", "x" "y". case, colors individuals/variables automatically controlled qualities ("cos2"), contributions ("contrib"), coordinates (x^2 + y^2 , "coord"), x values("x") y values("y"). use automatic coloring (cos2, contrib, ....), make sure habillage ="none". col.ind.sup color supplementary individuals alpha.ind, alpha.var, alpha.axes controls transparency individual, variable, group axes colors, respectively. value can variate 0 (total transparency) 1 (transparency). Default value 1. Possible values include also : "cos2", "contrib", "coord", "x" "y". case, transparency individual/variable colors automatically controlled qualities ("cos2"), contributions ("contrib"), coordinates (x^2 + y^2 , "coord"), x values("x") y values("y"). use , make sure habillage ="none". shape.ind, shape.var point shapes individuals, variables, groups axes col.quali.var.sup color supplementary qualitative variables. (default, partial = NULL partial points drawn). Use partial = "" visualize partial points individuals. col.partial color partial individuals. default, points colored according groups. ... title: Visualize Multiple Factor Analysis — fviz_mfa
code: # Compute Multiple Factor Analysis library("FactoMineR") data(wine) res.mfa <- MFA(wine, group=c(2,5,3,10,9,2), type=c("n",rep("s",5)),                ncp=5, name.group=c("orig","olf","vis","olfag","gust","ens"),                num.group.sup=c(1,6), graph=FALSE)                 # Eigenvalues/variances of dimensions fviz_screeplot(res.mfa)  # Group of variables fviz_mfa_var(res.mfa, "group")  # Quantitative variables fviz_mfa_var(res.mfa, "quanti.var", palette = "jco",    col.var.sup = "violet", repel = TRUE) #> Error in `[.data.frame`(X$call$X, rownames(ind), grp, drop = FALSE): undefined columns selected # Graph of individuals colored by cos2 fviz_mfa_ind(res.mfa, col.ind = "cos2",    gradient.cols = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800", "#FC4E07"),   repel = TRUE)  # Partial individuals fviz_mfa_ind(res.mfa, partial = "all")  #> Warning: TRE pattern compilation error 'Invalid contents of {}' #> Error in gsub("([\\.^$|()\\[\\]{}*+?\\\\])", "\\\\\\1", group.names): invalid regular expression '([\.^$|()\[\]{}*+?\\])', reason 'Invalid contents of {}' # Partial axes fviz_mfa_axes(res.mfa)    # Graph of categorical variable categories # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ data(poison) res.mfa <- MFA(poison, group=c(2,2,5,6), type=c("s","n","n","n"),                name.group=c("desc","desc2","symptom","eat"),                num.group.sup=1:2, graph=FALSE)  # Plot of qualitative variables fviz_mfa_var(res.mfa, "quali.var")       # Biplot of categorical variable categories and individuals # +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++  # Use repel = TRUE to avoid overplotting grp <- as.factor(poison[, "Vomiting"]) fviz_mfa_quali_biplot(res.mfa, repel = FALSE, col.var = "#E7B800",    habillage = grp, addEllipses = TRUE, ellipse.level = 0.95)

what: Dertermining and Visualizing the Optimal Number of Clusters — fviz_nbclust
title: Dertermining and Visualizing the Optimal Number of Clusters — fviz_nbclust
text: Partitioning methods, k-means clustering require   users specify number clusters generated. fviz_nbclust(): Dertemines visualize optimal number   clusters using different methods: within cluster sums squares,   average silhouette gap statistics. fviz_gap_stat(): Visualize gap statistic generated   function clusGap() [cluster package]. optimal   number clusters specified using "firstmax" method   (?cluster::clustGap). Read :   Determining    optimal number clusters

title: Dertermining and Visualizing the Optimal Number of Clusters — fviz_nbclust
code: fviz_nbclust(   x,   FUNcluster = NULL,   method = c("silhouette", "wss", "gap_stat"),   diss = NULL,   k.max = 10,   nboot = 100,   verbose = interactive(),   barfill = "steelblue",   barcolor = "steelblue",   linecolor = "steelblue",   print.summary = TRUE,   ... )  fviz_gap_stat(   gap_stat,   linecolor = "steelblue",   maxSE = list(method = "firstSEmax", SE.factor = 1) )

title: Dertermining and Visualizing the Optimal Number of Clusters — fviz_nbclust
text: x numeric matrix data frame. function fviz_nbclust(), x can results function NbClust(). FUNcluster partitioning function accepts first argument (data) matrix like x, second argument, say k, k >= 2, number clusters desired, returns list component named cluster contains grouping observations. Allowed values include: kmeans, cluster::pam, cluster::clara, cluster::fanny, hcut, etc. argument required x output function NbClust::NbClust(). method method used estimating optimal number clusters. Possible values "silhouette" (average silhouette width), "wss" (total within sum square) "gap_stat" (gap statistics). diss dist object produced dist(), .e.: diss = dist(x, method = "euclidean"). Used compute average silhouette width clusters, within sum square hierarchical clustering. NULL, dist(x) computed default method = "euclidean" k.max maximum number clusters consider, must least two. nboot integer, number Monte Carlo ("bootstrap") samples. Used determining number clusters using gap statistic. verbose logical value. TRUE, result progress printed. barfill, barcolor fill color outline color bars linecolor color lines print.summary logical value. true, optimal number clusters printed fviz_nbclust(). ... optionally arguments FUNcluster() gap_stat object class "clusGap" returned function clusGap() [cluster package] maxSE list containing parameters (method SE.factor) determining location maximum gap statistic (Read documentation ?cluster::maxSE). Allowed values maxSE$method include: "globalmax": simply corresponds global maximum, .e., .max(gap) "firstmax": gives location first local maximum "Tibs2001SEmax": uses criterion, Tibshirani et al (2001) proposed: "smallest k gap(k) >= gap(k+1) - s(k+1)". also possible use "smallest k gap(k) >= gap(k+1) - SE.factor*s(k+1)" SE.factor numeric value can 1 (default), 2, 3, etc. "firstSEmax": location first f() value larger first local maximum minus SE.factor * SE.f, .e, within "f S.E." range maximum. see ?cluster::maxSE options

title: Dertermining and Visualizing the Optimal Number of Clusters — fviz_nbclust
text: fviz_nbclust, fviz_gap_stat: return ggplot2

title: Dertermining and Visualizing the Optimal Number of Clusters — fviz_nbclust
text: default method "firstSEmax" (developed Martin Maechler, 2012)   recommended robust alternative "Tibs2001SEmax". original   Tibshirani method can overly conservative often returns k=1   standard deviations large relative gap differences. "firstSEmax"   method finds smallest k within one standard error first local   maximum, providing stable results practice.

title: Dertermining and Visualizing the Optimal Number of Clusters — fviz_nbclust
text: Alboukadel Kassambara alboukadel.kassambara@gmail.com

title: Dertermining and Visualizing the Optimal Number of Clusters — fviz_nbclust
code: set.seed(123)  # Data preparation # +++++++++++++++ data("iris") head(iris) #>   Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species #> 1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 2          4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa #> 4          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa #> 5          5.0         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa # Remove species column (5) and scale the data iris.scaled <- scale(iris[, -5])   # Optimal number of clusters in the data # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ # Examples are provided only for kmeans, but # you can also use cluster::pam (for pam) or #  hcut (for hierarchical clustering)   ### Elbow method (look at the knee) # Elbow method for kmeans fviz_nbclust(iris.scaled, kmeans, method = "wss") + geom_vline(xintercept = 3, linetype = 2)   # Average silhouette for kmeans fviz_nbclust(iris.scaled, kmeans, method = "silhouette")   ### Gap statistic library(cluster) set.seed(123) # Compute gap statistic for kmeans # we used B = 10 for demo. Recommended value is ~500 gap_stat <- clusGap(iris.scaled, FUN = kmeans, nstart = 25,  K.max = 10, B = 10)  print(gap_stat, method = "firstmax") #> Clustering Gap statistic ["clusGap"] from call: #> clusGap(x = iris.scaled, FUNcluster = kmeans, K.max = 10, B = 10, nstart = 25) #> B=10 simulated reference sets, k = 1..10; spaceH0="scaledPCA" #>  --> Number of clusters (method 'firstmax'): 3 #>           logW   E.logW       gap      SE.sim #>  [1,] 4.534565 4.745781 0.2112157 0.024271468 #>  [2,] 4.021316 4.481045 0.4597287 0.023247363 #>  [3,] 3.806577 4.287108 0.4805310 0.022005009 #>  [4,] 3.699263 4.138042 0.4387785 0.022976513 #>  [5,] 3.589284 4.046911 0.4576270 0.018998839 #>  [6,] 3.522810 3.971789 0.4489795 0.013118375 #>  [7,] 3.448288 3.906691 0.4584031 0.011975368 #>  [8,] 3.379870 3.851128 0.4712584 0.008759733 #>  [9,] 3.310088 3.801559 0.4914709 0.007393207 #> [10,] 3.278659 3.757545 0.4788863 0.009164325 fviz_gap_stat(gap_stat)    # Gap statistic for hierarchical clustering gap_stat <- clusGap(iris.scaled, FUN = hcut, K.max = 10, B = 10) fviz_gap_stat(gap_stat)

title: Visualize Principal Component Analysis — fviz_pca
text: Principal component analysis (PCA) reduces dimensionality   multivariate data, two three can visualized graphically   minimal loss information. fviz_pca() provides ggplot2-based elegant   visualization PCA outputs : ) prcomp princomp [built-R   stats], ii) PCA [FactoMineR], iii) dudi.pca [ade4] epPCA   [ExPosition]. Read :   Principal    Component Analysis  fviz_pca_ind(): Graph individuals fviz_pca_var():   Graph variables fviz_pca_biplot(): Biplot individuals   variables fviz_pca(): alias fviz_pca_biplot() Note , fviz_pca_xxx() functions wrapper around core   function fviz(), also wrapper around   function ggscatter() [ggpubrplus]. Therefore, arguments,   passed function fviz() ggscatter(), can specified   fviz_pca_ind() fviz_pca_var().

title: Visualize Principal Component Analysis — fviz_pca

Allowed values NULL list containing arguments name, cos2 contrib: name: character vector containing individuals/variables drawn cos2: cos2 [0, 1], ex: 0.6, individuals/variables cos2 > 0.6 drawn. cos2 > 1, ex: 5, top 5 individuals/variables highest cos2 drawn. contrib: contrib > 1, ex: 5,  top 5 individuals/variables highest contrib drawn col.quanti.sup color quantitative supplementary variables. col.circle color correlation circle. Used X PCA output. gradient.cols vector colors use n-colour gradient. Allowed values include brewer ggsci color palettes. label text specifying elements labelled. Default value "". Allowed values "none" combination c("ind", "ind.sup", "quali", "var", "quanti.sup"). "ind" can used label active individuals. "ind.sup" supplementary individuals. "quali" supplementary qualitative variables. "var" active variables. "quanti.sup" quantitative supplementary variables. invisible text specifying elements hidden plot. Default value "none". Allowed values combination c("ind", "ind.sup", "quali", "var", "quanti.sup"). title title graph biplot.type type biplot scaling fviz_pca_biplot(). Options : "auto" (default): Uses range-based rescaling visualization "form": Form biplot (Gabriel, 1971). Distances individuals     approximate Euclidean distances. Use focus individual relationships. "covariance": Covariance biplot (Gabriel, 1971). Angles variable     vectors approximate correlations, lengths approximate standard deviations.     Use focus variable relationships. Note: "form" "covariance" scaling requires prcomp princomp objects.

title: Visualize Principal Component Analysis — fviz_pca
text: ggplot

title: Visualize Principal Component Analysis — fviz_pca
text: Alboukadel Kassambara alboukadel.kassambara@gmail.com

title: Visualize Principal Component Analysis — fviz_pca
code: # \donttest{ # Principal component analysis # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ data(iris) res.pca <- prcomp(iris[, -5],  scale = TRUE)  # Graph of individuals # +++++++++++++++++++++  # Default plot # Use repel = TRUE to avoid overplotting (slow if many points) fviz_pca_ind(res.pca, col.ind = "#00AFBB",    repel = TRUE)     # 1. Control automatically the color of individuals     # using the "cos2" or the contributions "contrib"    # cos2 = the quality of the individuals on the factor map # 2. To keep only point or text use geom = "point" or geom = "text". # 3. Change themes using ggtheme: http://www.sthda.com/english/wiki/ggplot2-themes  fviz_pca_ind(res.pca, col.ind="cos2", geom = "point",    gradient.cols = c("white", "#2E9FDF", "#FC4E07" ))   # Color individuals by groups, add concentration ellipses # Change group colors using RColorBrewer color palettes # Read more: http://www.sthda.com/english/wiki/ggplot2-colors # Remove labels: label = "none". fviz_pca_ind(res.pca, label="none", habillage=iris$Species,      addEllipses=TRUE, ellipse.level=0.95, palette = "Dark2")                      # Change group colors manually # Read more: http://www.sthda.com/english/wiki/ggplot2-colors fviz_pca_ind(res.pca, label="none", habillage=iris$Species,      addEllipses=TRUE, ellipse.level=0.95,      palette = c("#999999", "#E69F00", "#56B4E9"))         # Select and visualize some individuals (ind) with select.ind argument.  # - ind with cos2 >= 0.96: select.ind = list(cos2 = 0.96)  # - Top 20 ind according to the cos2: select.ind = list(cos2 = 20)  # - Top 20 contributing individuals: select.ind = list(contrib = 20)  # - Select ind by names: select.ind = list(name = c("23", "42", "119") )    # Example: Select the top 40 according to the cos2 fviz_pca_ind(res.pca, select.ind = list(cos2 = 40))     # Graph of variables # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++    # Default plot fviz_pca_var(res.pca, col.var = "steelblue")    # Control variable colors using their contributions fviz_pca_var(res.pca, col.var = "contrib",     gradient.cols = c("white", "blue", "red"),    ggtheme = theme_minimal())         # Biplot of individuals and variables # ++++++++++++++++++++++++++ # Keep only the labels for variables # Change the color by groups, add ellipses fviz_pca_biplot(res.pca, label = "var", habillage=iris$Species,                addEllipses=TRUE, ellipse.level=0.95,                ggtheme = theme_minimal())   # Biplot types (Gabriel, 1971): # Form biplot - focus on individual distances fviz_pca_biplot(res.pca, biplot.type = "form",                label = "var", habillage = iris$Species)  # Covariance biplot - focus on variable correlations fviz_pca_biplot(res.pca, biplot.type = "covariance",                label = "var", habillage = iris$Species)    # }

title: Visualize Silhouette Information from Clustering — fviz_silhouette

title: Visualize Silhouette Information from Clustering — fviz_silhouette
text: Alboukadel Kassambara alboukadel.kassambara@gmail.com

title: Visualize Silhouette Information from Clustering — fviz_silhouette
code: set.seed(123)  # Data preparation # +++++++++++++++ data("iris") head(iris) #>   Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species #> 1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 2          4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa #> 4          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa #> 5          5.0         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa #> 6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa # Remove species column (5) and scale the data iris.scaled <- scale(iris[, -5])  # K-means clustering # +++++++++++++++++++++ km.res <- kmeans(iris.scaled, 3, nstart = 2)  # Visualize kmeans clustering fviz_cluster(km.res, iris[, -5], ellipse.type = "norm")+ theme_minimal()   # Visualize silhouhette information require("cluster") sil <- silhouette(km.res$cluster, dist(iris.scaled)) fviz_silhouette(sil) #>   cluster size ave.sil.width #> 1       1   50          0.64 #> 2       2   53          0.39 #> 3       3   47          0.35   # Identify observation with negative silhouette neg_sil_index <- which(sil[, "sil_width"] < 0) sil[neg_sil_index, , drop = FALSE] #>      cluster neighbor   sil_width #> [1,]       3        2 -0.01058434 #> [2,]       3        2 -0.02489394 if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # PAM clustering # ++++++++++++++++++++ require(cluster) pam.res <- pam(iris.scaled, 3) # Visualize pam clustering fviz_cluster(pam.res, ellipse.type = "norm")+ theme_minimal() # Visualize silhouhette information fviz_silhouette(pam.res)  # Hierarchical clustering # ++++++++++++++++++++++++ # Use hcut() which compute hclust and cut the tree hc.cut <- hcut(iris.scaled, k = 3, hc_method = "complete") # Visualize dendrogram fviz_dend(hc.cut, show_labels = FALSE, rect = TRUE) # Visualize silhouhette information fviz_silhouette(hc.cut) } # }

title: Assessing Clustering Tendency — get_clust_tendency
text: applying cluster methods, first step assess   whether data clusterable, process defined assessing   clustering tendency. get_clust_tendency() assesses clustering tendency   using Hopkins' statistic visual approach. ordered dissimilarity   image (ODI) shown. Objects belonging cluster displayed   consecutive order using hierarchical clustering. details   interpretation, see   STHDA    website: Assessing clustering tendency.

title: Assessing Clustering Tendency — get_clust_tendency
code: get_clust_tendency(   data,   n,   graph = TRUE,   gradient = list(low = "red", mid = "white", high = "blue"),   seed = 123 )

title: Assessing Clustering Tendency — get_clust_tendency
text: data numeric data frame matrix. Columns variables rows samples. Computation done rows (samples) default. want calculate Hopkins statistic variables, transpose data . n number points selected sample space also number points selected given sample(data). graph logical value; TRUE ordered dissimilarity image (ODI) shown. gradient list containing three elements specifying colors low, mid high values ordered dissimilarity image. element "mid" can take value NULL. seed integer specifying seed random number generator. Specify seed reproducible results.

title: Assessing Clustering Tendency — get_clust_tendency
text: list containing elements: - hopkins_stat Hopkins statistic value - plot ordered dissimilarity image. generated using   function fviz_dist(dist.obj).

title: Assessing Clustering Tendency — get_clust_tendency
text: Hopkins statistic: value Hopkins statistic close 1 (far 0.5), can conclude dataset significantly clusterable. statistic calculated using correct formula Cross Jain (1982) exponent d=D D dimensionality (number columns) data. null hypothesis spatial randomness, Hopkins statistic follows Beta(n, n) distribution. Note interpretation: function returns Hopkins statistic H values close 1 indicate clusterable data. packages (e.g., performance::check_clusterstructure) return 1-H, values close 0 indicate clusterability. Always check documentation specific implementation using. VAT (Visual Assessment cluster Tendency): VAT detects clustering tendency visual form counting number square shaped dark (colored) blocks along diagonal VAT image.

title: Assessing Clustering Tendency — get_clust_tendency
text: Alboukadel Kassambara alboukadel.kassambara@gmail.com

title: Assessing Clustering Tendency — get_clust_tendency
code: data(iris)  # Clustering tendency gradient_col = list(low = "steelblue", high = "white") get_clust_tendency(iris[,-5], n = 50, gradient = gradient_col) #> $hopkins_stat #> [1] 0.9949145 #>  #> $plot  #>      # Random uniformly distributed dataset # (without any inherent clusters) set.seed(123) random_df <- apply(iris[, -5], 2,                     function(x){runif(length(x), min(x), max(x))}                    ) get_clust_tendency(random_df, n = 50, gradient = gradient_col) #> $hopkins_stat #> [1] 0.4820419 #>  #> $plot  #>

what: Computes Hierarchical Clustering and Cut the Tree — hcut
title: Computes Hierarchical Clustering and Cut the Tree — hcut
text: Computes hierarchical clustering (hclust, agnes, diana) cut tree k clusters. also accepts correlation based distance measure methods "pearson", "spearman" "kendall".

title: Computes Hierarchical Clustering and Cut the Tree — hcut
code: hcut(   x,   k = 2,   isdiss = inherits(x, "dist"),   hc_func = c("hclust", "agnes", "diana"),   hc_method = "ward.D2",   hc_metric = "euclidean",   stand = FALSE,   graph = FALSE,   ... )

title: Computes Hierarchical Clustering and Cut the Tree — hcut
text: x numeric matrix, numeric data frame dissimilarity matrix. k number clusters generated. isdiss logical value specifying wether x dissimilarity matrix. hc_func hierarchical clustering function used. Default value "hclust". Possible values one "hclust", "agnes", "diana". Abbreviation allowed. hc_method agglomeration method used (?hclust) hclust() agnes(): "ward.D", "ward.D2", "single", "complete", "average", ... hc_metric character string specifying metric used calculating dissimilarities observations. Allowed values accepted function dist() [including "euclidean", "manhattan", "maximum",  "canberra", "binary", "minkowski"] correlation based distance measures ["pearson", "spearman" "kendall"]. stand logical value; default FALSE. TRUE, data standardized using function scale(). Measurements standardized variable (column), subtracting variable's mean value dividing variable's standard deviation. graph logical value. TRUE, dendrogram displayed. ... used.

title: Computes Hierarchical Clustering and Cut the Tree — hcut
text: object class "hcut" containing result standard function used (read documentation hclust, agnes, diana). includes also: cluster: cluster assignement observations cutting tree nbclust: number clusters silinfo: silhouette information observations (k > 1) size: size clusters data: matrix containing original  standardized data (stand = TRUE)

title: Computes Hierarchical Clustering and Cut the Tree — hcut
code: # \donttest{ data(USArrests)  # Compute hierarchical clustering and cut into 4 clusters res <- hcut(USArrests, k = 4, stand = TRUE)  # Cluster assignements of observations res$cluster #>        Alabama         Alaska        Arizona       Arkansas     California  #>              1              2              2              3              2  #>       Colorado    Connecticut       Delaware        Florida        Georgia  #>              2              3              3              2              1  #>         Hawaii          Idaho       Illinois        Indiana           Iowa  #>              3              4              2              3              4  #>         Kansas       Kentucky      Louisiana          Maine       Maryland  #>              3              3              1              4              2  #>  Massachusetts       Michigan      Minnesota    Mississippi       Missouri  #>              3              2              4              1              3  #>        Montana       Nebraska         Nevada  New Hampshire     New Jersey  #>              4              4              2              4              3  #>     New Mexico       New York North Carolina   North Dakota           Ohio  #>              2              2              1              4              3  #>       Oklahoma         Oregon   Pennsylvania   Rhode Island South Carolina  #>              3              3              3              3              1  #>   South Dakota      Tennessee          Texas           Utah        Vermont  #>              4              1              2              3              4  #>       Virginia     Washington  West Virginia      Wisconsin        Wyoming  #>              3              3              4              4              3  # Size of clusters res$size #> [1]  7 12 19 12  # Visualize the dendrogram fviz_dend(res, rect = TRUE)   # Visualize the silhouette fviz_silhouette(res) #>   cluster size ave.sil.width #> 1       1    7          0.46 #> 2       2   12          0.29 #> 3       3   19          0.26 #> 4       4   12          0.43   # Visualize clusters as scatter plots fviz_cluster(res)  # }

title: Hierarchical k-means clustering — hkmeans
text: final k-means clustering solution sensitive initial random selection cluster centers. function provides solution using hybrid approach combining hierarchical clustering k-means methods. procedure explained "Details" section. Read :   Hybrid hierarchical k-means clustering optimizing clustering outputs. hkmeans(): compute hierarchical k-means clustering print.hkmeans(): prints result hkmeans hkmeans_tree(): plots initial dendrogram

title: Hierarchical k-means clustering — hkmeans
code: hkmeans(   x,   k,   hc.metric = "euclidean",   hc.method = "ward.D2",   iter.max = 10,   km.algorithm = "Hartigan-Wong" )  # S3 method for class 'hkmeans' print(x, ...)  hkmeans_tree(hkmeans, rect.col = NULL, ...)

title: Hierarchical k-means clustering — hkmeans
text: x numeric matrix, data frame vector k number clusters generated hc.metric distance measure used. Possible values "euclidean", "maximum", "manhattan", "canberra", "binary" "minkowski" (see ?dist). hc.method agglomeration method used. Possible values include "ward.D", "ward.D2", "single", "complete", "average", "mcquitty", "median""centroid" (see ?hclust). iter.max maximum number iterations allowed k-means. km.algorithm algorithm used kmeans (see ?kmeans). ... others arguments passed function plot.hclust(); (see ? plot.hclust) hkmeans object class hkmeans (returned function hkmeans()) rect.col Vector border colors rectangles around clusters dendrogram

title: Hierarchical k-means clustering — hkmeans
text: hkmeans returns object class "hkmeans" containing following components: elements returned standard function kmeans() (see ?kmeans) data: data used analysis hclust: object class "hclust" generated function hclust()

title: Hierarchical k-means clustering — hkmeans
text: procedure follow: 1. Compute hierarchical clustering 2. Cut tree k-clusters 3. compute center (.e mean) cluster 4. k-means using set cluster centers (defined step 3) initial cluster centers. Optimize clustering. means final optimized partitioning obtained step 4 might different initial partitioning obtained step 2. Consider mainly result displayed fviz_cluster().

title: Hierarchical k-means clustering — hkmeans

vector: #>        Alabama         Alaska        Arizona       Arkansas     California  #>              1              2              2              1              2  #>       Colorado    Connecticut  #>              3              4              2              3              4  #>         Kansas       Kentucky      Louisiana          Maine       Maryland  #>              3              4
